message_2:
To solve the complex number equation $z^2 + 3z + 10 = 0$, we can use the quadratic formula:

$$z = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}$$

In this case, $a = 1$, $b = 3$, and $c = 10$. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

$$z = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{3^2 - 4(1)(10)}}{2(1)}$$

$$z = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{9 - 40}}{2}$$

$$z = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{-31}}{2}$$

Since the discriminant is negative, we know that the solutions will be complex numbers. We can rewrite the square root of a negative number as the product of the square root of the positive number and the imaginary unit $i$:

$$z = \frac{-3 \pm i\sqrt{31}}{2}$$

So, the two complex solutions are:

$$z_1 = \frac{-3 + i\sqrt{31}}{2}$$

$$z_2 = \frac{-3 - i\sqrt{31}}{2}$$
